children.subject: Probably the curve, since the course is self-selecting and is taken by all those with an affinity for that kind of content. However, this is starting to change a little due to the spreading belief that 126 is a must to do well in 189 (not actually true if you take it with a professor not named Sahai, but people buy into it anyways), leading to more people taking it in the hopes of doing well in 189, including those who otherwise wouldn't.

history.content:
The homeworks are pretty challenging (I would describe them as the next level after the CS70 probability homeworks). If you found the probability part of CS70 easy, then the homeworks might not be as hard for you.

The tests are actually easier than the homeworks, and this is the case for most mathy classes I have taken (126, 127, 189).

The curve is actually pretty fair, at least when I took it. The instructors know it is a challenging class relative to other classes here, and the grades are assigned with this in mind. The class is self-selecting, but there is an influx in recent semesters of people taking it because others told them to, as mentioned below, which balance each other out a little.

All-in-all, it is a class that deserves its reputation of being one of the most rewarding and well-organized upper division classes. So, despite the difficulty of the class, I would say it is definitely worth taking if you are willing to put in the time and take it seriously.

Is it the homework? The tests? The curve? I would love to learn more probability but I would be taking 126 with 2 other CS classes so I'm curious as to what to expect for that class.

I will have taken EE16A/B and 70, so my math skills are basically mature in a sense.
history.subject: What makes 126 challenging?

history.content: Is it the homework? The tests? The curve? I would love to learn more probability but I would be taking 126 with 2 other CS classes so I'm curious as to what to expect for that class.
